data.author: Kevin Bobevin

data.text: I think you are confusing the Ho Chi Minh trail with Highway 1 that connects north and south Vietnam . The Ho Chi Minh trail is not a marked trail and never was a marked trail. It was a network of jungle paths on the Vietnam/Lao border that were used to transport soldiers and weapons during the war. But it has never been a route that was mapped or used for regular transport.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: Ok thanks, ill take the Google maps " ho chi minh" trail it will be easier than biking in the jungle
data.author: Kevin Bobevin

data.text: there is now a Ho Chi Minh highway which runs North to south mainly along the western border of Vietnam. Much of it is stunningly beautiful and quite remote but the southern section is quite busy and filled with trucks and sleeper buses and definitely to be avoided.
data.author: Simon Nelson

data.text: It's not the Ho Chi Minh trail though . Even if they might try to promote it as such towards foreign visitors.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: agreed however it is more similar to the Ho Chi Minh trial than highway 1 and it's easy to see where the confusion might arise.
data.author: Simon Nelson

data.text: There are a couple of blogs on crazyguyonabike. We didn't do it as it's hilly and at times big distances between things. Very popular with motorcyclists. I believe the road is good.
data.author: Karen Brown

data.author: Phil Joyce

data.text: it's like tesco but better
data.author: Kevin Bobevin

data.text: Yes. I went from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh. Get visa - took longer for me than they said; ended up having to pay someone online while in airport in HK to do a special quick visa (which means an immigration officer has a side hussle but it work though it costs quite a bit). Buy flight. Get hotel for first night to put bike together unless you have time to do it at airport though I wouldn't recommend that if you aren't a global continuous rider with experience at winging it. Head out. Get a side mirror. Rules of the road in Vietnam: priority goes to the bigger the vehicle - even if it means they are driving on your side of the road to avoid pot holes. Red lights are for decoration. Once you are moving, don't stop or your mess up the organized chaos which could lead to an accident. They are good at avoiding each other while driving in all directions (specially in the bigger cities), especially the scooters. Wild camping is hard to find. With all the rain, humidity, and bugs, and cheap accommodations everywhere, even in small villages, it's the best/easiest option after cycling for the day. As far as route: ask locals.. avoid the main highways unless there's no option. Don't ride at night too much because that's when the drunks come out. Your back lights could make them wonder what it is and accidentally, drunkenly, swerve into you.
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: thanks, I live in Thailand and have been to Vietnam once before, I know about the road tax it seems to be common in South east Asia thanks for your advice . How was the route? Is it mostly downhill?
data.author: Kevin Bobevin

data.text: I like climbing mountains and go where locals suggests to see the "secret" sites or views so I'm not one to recommend the "easy" routes. I tour for almost 5 years now so I'm never in a rush unless it's for visa
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: I've had friends do Hanoi to HCMC. A bunch of people do it annually for charity. It's called the H2H ride. I'd follow that route even if you don't join H2H. The real HCM trail goes into Laos and Cambodia.
data.author: Edgar Kim

data.text:
Do you mean cycling from Hanoi to Saigon, or are you actually talking about the Ho Chi Minh trail? Because it's not the same thing. The Ho Chi Minh trail is not an official trail, but a network of unmarked jungle trails that was used for guerilla warfare against the US and south Vietnamese army in the 1960's and 70's. Cycling between Hanoi and Saigon is perfectly doable. Have done it twice myself. I have a bit of general info on my blog about cycling in Vietnam, in case you are interested. https://travellingclaus.com/cycling-vietnam/
Tips and advice for cycling Vietnam. ‚Äì Travelling Claus
travellingclaus.com
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: I have, check out intrepid travel to see their recommended route.

data.text: Yes I have done this self supported (not through a tour guide company) definitely recommend!
data.author: Anna Gostine

data.text: I did from North to South. Great scenery and good road conditions. Much better then the roads at the coast line
data.author: Ilana Martini Jones

data.text: The Viet Cong many times.
data.author: Ed Weingarten

data.text: I've done Ha Noi to HCMC twice as part of longer trips, been over DBP and Loa Cai too.
data.author: GS McFaul

data.text: I've cycled sections of Vietnam and want to do a full north to south once the visa situation improves. Right now you'll need to do a visa run after 30 days. Check out the Vietnam Coracle, though this is more a motorbike website. I would start in Mai Chau and follow the Ho Chi Minh Road down through Pu Luong and through to Phong Nha or right through to Da Nang and then hit the coast for the south central regions. There are some amazing quiet coastal roads and personally I would think this probably a better experience than the ho chi Minh Road all the way through. Phu Yen province is wonderful. It's not that hard to stay off highway one and on the back roads.
data.author: Sonia Maclean
